rev.comment: /* Necrophilia as represented in the arts */
rev.diff:
Line 160: Line 160:
Many of [[death Metal]] band [[Cannibal Corpse]]'s songs are about necrophilia, most notably the song "Necropedophile."
Many of [[death Metal]] band [[Cannibal Corpse]]'s songs are about necrophilia, most notably the song "Necropedophile."
â
The song "Necromancing" (it's title being a play on the words "[[Necromancy]]" and "[[Romance|Romancing}}" by [[Gnarles Barkley]] tells the story of a man who kills the woman he desires and then reanimates her corpse as a [[zombie]] to be his lover.
+
The song "Necromancing" (it's title being a play on the words "[[Necromancy]]" and "[[Romance|Romancing]]" by [[Gnarles Barkley]] tells the story of a man who kills the woman he desires and then reanimates her corpse as a [[zombie]] to be his lover.
The opening line of the [[Cradle of Filth]] song "Lord Abortion" from their album [[Midian (album)|Midian]], ("care for a little necrophilia, hm?") is a quote from Terry Gilliam's Brazil (voiced by Kim Greist in the film but delivered on the song by Toni King, the wife of the band's vocalist/co-creator Dani Filth).
The opening line of the [[Cradle of Filth]] song "Lord Abortion" from their album [[Midian (album)|Midian]], ("care for a little necrophilia, hm?") is a quote from Terry Gilliam's Brazil (voiced by Kim Greist in the film but delivered on the song by Toni King, the wife of the band's vocalist/co-creator Dani Filth).
